questions.question: 1. Which among the following represents a stack?

answers.a: People waiting at a counter, where the action of popping is when someone has been served at the counter
answers.b: A hand of bangles where pushing is wearing a new bangle
answers.c: A pile of plates at a dinner party

explanations.a: Incorrect. This is a queue, not a stack, as people are served in the order they arrive (FIFO).
explanations.b: Incorrect. Bangles are added and removed from the same end, but the analogy is less direct than a pile of plates.
explanations.c: Correct. A pile of plates is a classic example of a stack (LIFO).
explanations.d: Incorrect. A merry-go-round does not represent stack or queue behavior.

questions.question: 2. What is the time complexity of push operation in a stack? What is the time complexity of pop operation in a stack?

explanations.a: Incorrect. Both push and pop operations in a stack are O(1) in standard implementations.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Both push and pop operations in a stack are O(1) in standard implementations.
explanations.c: Incorrect. Both push and pop operations in a stack are O(1) in standard implementations.
explanations.d: Correct. Both push and pop operations in a stack are O(1) in standard implementations.

questions.question: 3. Consider these operations on an empty stack: push(3), push(5), pop(), push(10), push(11), pop(), push(100). What will be the stack configuration (first number is top of the stack, last is the bottom)

explanations.a: Correct. The stack after the operations will be [100, 10, 3] (top to bottom).
explanations.b: Incorrect. This does not match the stack configuration after the given operations.
explanations.c: Incorrect. This does not match the stack configuration after the given operations.
explanations.d: Incorrect. Option a is the correct configuration.
